text:
World’s Culture Ministers fret over destruction of historical, cultural heritage through conflict Published on : Saturday, August 8, 2015
Ministers of culture gathered for a recent United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (Unesco) meeting have expressed concern over the destruction of historical infrastructure and pieces of art contained on the world heritage list as a result of armed conflicts around the world.
This was stated by the Angolan Minister of Culture, Rosa Cruz e Silva, upon her arrival at the 4 de Fevereiro International Airport in Luanda Thursday from Italy, where she attended the International Conference of Ministers of Culture held in conjunction the 2015 World Expo taking place in Milan.
According to her, the ministers were concerned over the destruction of historical and cultural heritage in several countries as a result of wars, ethnic violence, religious and military conflicts, terrorism or even looting of assets in Syria, Iraq and other regions of the world.
She said the situation in Syria was very worrying, because it is a territory considered one of the cradles of civilization, whose museums were brutally looted and destroyed.
In Mali, he added, Timbuktu’s monuments and documents were destroyed and such actions occur in many places in different UNESCO member countries.
Angola reported that the African continent, as the cradle of humanity, had been greatly affected by acts of terrorism and illicit trafficking of valuable pieces.
